>I'm spending a lot of time passing new method into the testclass and write 
>a
>"test_" in front of it (and oftenly forget to do it, too).
>I made a try to automate the creation of stubs for all existing methods of 
>a
>class using the Reflection API (e.g. from myProcedure(int A, String B) to
>test_myProcedure_int_A_String_B. The final goal would be to have the tool
>comparing the class to the test_class and create stubs for new methods
>while leaving the existing ones untouched. <snip />

Folks, I know I'm a broken record on this one, but...

...let's not forget that testing is a mindful activity, and not a mindless 
activity. Generating test stubs, especially from classes already written, 
relieves you of the need to think about what you're testing. This is a bad 
thing, and often a Bad Thing.

Do you really need to test every method on your class? Can you remove them 
instead? Can you consolidate them into a smaller number of methods? Should 
they be on other classes? These are all questions that you should ask 
*especially* before writing tests for code already written. Particularly if 
you didn't write the code but need to write the tests. By writing the tests, 
one by one, thinking clearly about what feature (not method) you're testing, 
you are forced to answer all these questions. This helps your design. That's 
a Good Thing.

If the original poster has already thought of all that and decided that 
generating test stubs is appropriate, then that's great; but if not, he 
should reconsider before diving in. I've been there, and it wasn't a fun 
trip.

Don't mind me.

J. B. Rainsberger
